大约十年前，我获得了数学和计算学位，对从事数学和编程的职业抱有浓厚的兴趣，但不知道如何去做。首先也是最重要的是，我决定在大学毕业后留在曼彻斯特，而不是在我搬回家后冒着被困在父母那里的风险。所以我和一个大学的朋友租了一套公寓，开始找工作。我花了很多时间在大学学习 Web 开发——不是从课程中学习，而是自学，因为课程远远落后。我很高兴使用 LAMP 堆栈制作网站，我觉得自己很有能力，而且我知道曼彻斯特地区有很多这样的工作——所以我开始申请“Web 开发人员”和“PHP 开发人员”以及各种类似的职位的本地公司。我的第一次面试是在斯托克波特的一家小公司做一般开发人员的工作——这份工作需要 Microsoft Access 经验，出于某种原因，这仍然是我认为自己拥有的东西，并且愿意向我所拥有的其他人承诺，这让我感到困惑我现在。我最终在面试中与公司老板进行了非常愉快的交谈。他问了一些关于数据分析的很棒的面试问题，我们花了大约 90 分钟的时间交谈——他对我在大学学习的东西很着迷——特别是数据可视化和动态系统与混沌。我确实得到了这份工作，但他为时已晚——我已经进行了第二次面试，他们要求我立即开始。我的第二次采访是在索尔福德一个老式工业区的办公楼里的一家名为 App Start 的公司（如果你把媒体城想象成索尔福德，索尔福德的其余部分会让人震惊）。由于低估了从火车站步行的距离，我一直在拖延时间，而我因匆忙赶到并试图找到这个地方而有点慌张。迎接我的是一个穿着沙滩裤和人字拖的男人。我穿着全套西装、衬衫、领带和漂亮的鞋子，我告诉他“我是来采访克里斯的”——他的回答“哦，克里斯不再在这里工作了”应该引起警报钟声，但是嘿，我年轻而天真。穿着人字拖的亚历克斯现在似乎掌权了。他问我申请了哪个职位——我说“网络开发人员”，他邀请我加入。大约有 15 到 20 人在台式 PC 上工作。有一个大沙发。地板是裸露的混凝土。在写有密码的白板之间，你可以看到墙壁上的涂鸦。在“面试”中，他试图在 Chris 的收件箱中找到我的简历，我向他展示了我制作的一些网站。他问我是否可以第二天来，做一天的工作作为试验——我照做了。第二天是星期五——我似乎记得建立一个社交网站的原型——虽然我不知道为什么。无论如何——他似乎认为我足够好所以他给了我这份工作——从周一开始——这对我来说很棒——我马上就找到了一份全职工作，这意味着我可以支付房租并开始我的职位- 在曼彻斯特的大学生活。但我一接受，他就问：“你明天有空吗？” ——我犹豫了一下，但还是回答了这个问题——“是的”。 “你能进来吗？”因为我不知道还能说什么，所以我说是的。同样，这应该是一个标志。业主是一位名叫安德鲁的年轻企业家，我听说他通过他的房地产开发和管理公司 Fresh Start Living 赚了数百万美元。他决定进入“应用程序”市场（请记住，这是 2011 年——iPhone 应用程序非常庞大），因此他决定给他的 IT 人员 (Alex) 一笔预算，聘请一些开发人员来制作大量应用程序。其中一个肯定会取得巨大的成功，他会赚到数百万美元。星期六我又回去了，发现办公室里没有任何人。我等了一会儿，但不知道该怎么办。我没有亚历克斯的联系电话。过了一会儿，他出现了。他一直在大楼的Fresh Start Living一侧。我们在办公室独自完成了一天的工作。他送我回家，我原定在星期一开始真正的工作。
我周一到达，并被告知我将从事的项目。简短的版本是我被告知我们必须在任何人回家之前完成它。我们一直待到晚上 9 点。那是我成为全职员工的第一天。所以在我的第一天，亚历克斯告诉我我将从事的项目叫做技能购买，并继续解释这个概念。这个想法类似于当时流行的拍卖网站，您可以对产品出价，但每次出价都需要付费——因此，如果您看到中标的 iPhone 为 1 便士，您可以出价 2 便士，但如果您出价高，你就失去了 2 便士——最终有人会以便宜的价格赢得它，而牺牲在他们之前出价的每个人的利益，公司就会发财。它们被称为便士拍卖，您可以在本文中了解它们：在线便士拍卖是一种赌博形式吗？无论如何——我被告知的想法是相似的，但你不是竞标，而是玩游戏（由我合作的游戏开发者制作的 Flash 或 Unity 游戏）——它就像一个街机游戏——获胜者得到奖品。您会购买积分，将积分用于玩游戏，如果您在比赛倒计时结束时成为最佳射手，那么您将赢得奖品。实际上，您会以 99% 的折扣赢得奖品，因为他们似乎认为这绕过了赌博法。在没有 Web 开发人员的情况下，实现这个想法非常棘手，Alex 一直在使用他自己的万事通技能将一些东西组合在一起。他有一些管理电子商务网站的经验（后来我发现他经营着自己的在线情趣用品店……），因此他使用 PHP 电子商务框架 Magento 组装了一个 Skill Buy 原型。他会在网站的管理区域添加产品（奖品），并修改模板以显示倒数计时器和东西。不知何故，亚历克斯承诺该网站将准备好在第二天向安德鲁展示 - 下午的某个时候，他开始感到压力，并对整个房间说“在完成之前没有人回家”。其中一位游戏开发者在 Unity 中制作了一个目标射击练习游戏，我们必须弄清楚如何将其嵌入网站并让游戏将玩家的分数提交给网站的 PHP 后端。我们不知道从哪里开始，但我们整个下午都在努力，一直到晚上，我们让它按照亚历克斯要求的任何标准工作，最后回家了。在接下来的几周里，我在这个网站上工作，我厌倦了被困在这个电子商务框架中——不得不使用它的超规范化 MySQL 数据库（EAV 模型），而且我正在构建的产品是这不是一家真正的商店——所以我问亚历克斯他是否介意我写一些定制的东西。我让自己的自定义 PHP/MySQL 站点快速启动并运行，不久我们就启动了该站点。我很高兴编写蹩脚的 PHP，实施可疑的安全保护（阻止人们发送虚假分数的微弱尝试），并学习诸如如何集成 Facebook 登录、PayPal 支付、使用 AJAX 以及与游戏开发人员合作以集成评分系统。我真的很喜欢在那里工作一段时间！这是一种解放，知道我正在按照自己的条件使用自学的网络开发技能 - 并因此获得报酬。这家应用程序公司由亚历克斯和一个叫利亚姆的 19 岁孩子经营，他的叔叔参与了房地产业务。不知何故，利亚姆获得了一项实验性的副业业务，以帮助他在大学的“实习年”。可能让您感到奇怪的一件事是奇异的图形。设计师为计划中的 iPhone 游戏制作了所有这些牛在场的图形 - 但他们搁置了它并告诉她在网站上重新使用它们。她讨厌他们被这样使用——这对其他人来说也没有意义。亚历克斯经常问你周六是否有空。前几次我说是的，只是多工作了一天——我想我认为我会自动获得加班费——但我没有。最终我学会了说不。
我加入后不久，一个叫 Bob 的人出现并担任了某种产品经理的工作，类似于 Alex 和 Liam。和利亚姆一样，他看起来还不错，但有点格格不入。他是亚历克斯的朋友。他曾经整天盯着谷歌分析，然后过来告诉我关于退回时间和推荐的事情。他过去常常在午饭后离开，无论出于何种原因，他赢得了“半职鲍勃”的绰号。不过他并没有坚持多久。一天，他正在与安德鲁会面，他显然已经看穿了他并且受够了。我开始发现，当安德鲁决定他不喜欢某人，而不是解雇他们时，他会尝试一下，让他们感到非常生气，他们想要离开。鲍勃走进门，把门砰地关在身后，大声自言自语“他不会那样跟我说话”，然后向房间宣布他“不再听安德鲁的狗屎了”，然后冲了出去。我们推出了这个网站，他们开始投放 Facebook 广告来宣传它。亚历克斯甚至订购了大量印刷材料和标志。我记得有一次，在送我回家的电梯时，他停下来下车，在一组交通信号灯的栏杆上用缆绳把一条技能购买横幅绑在了栏杆上。我们有人玩——注册后你会得到一些免费积分，有些人实际上也在购买积分。更便宜的噱头奖品的时间很短，我们有获奖者领取奖品——利亚姆把奖品寄出去了。我们在那里也有一些大奖，比如劳力士手表、一年的免费住宿和房子。这个想法是，如果网站获得足够的收入，安德鲁可以放弃使用 Fresh Start 的一些出租物业甚至房子。住宿和房子的时间为 3 个月，这肯定足以建立网站用户群。过了一会儿，安德鲁决定做出改变。您无需购买积分，而是购买游戏门票，只有当足够多的人购买门票时，游戏才会开放，以保证收入足以支付奖品成本。这基本上停止了网站上的所有活动。人们没有玩游戏和争夺奖品，他们只是在等待，几乎没有人有兴趣买票。这意味着该网站不再在奖品上花钱，因此它没有任何支出，但没有任何迹象表明它获得了所需的用户数量。在我的收件箱中搜索与 App Start 相关的任何内容时，我发现了这封来自 Andrew 的电子邮件，由 Alex 转发给我： Hi Ben – 这些是 Andrew 要求的技能购买更改。开始转发消息：为房产奖励制作一个技能购买部分，仅用于替换任何当前的房产部分 显示 3 个选项，讨论基于拥有现金的收益 1 栋联排别墅 1 套公寓 @ bispham 3 学生舱蒙哥马利 呼叫所有这些价值 100 k 加 A入场门票成本为 100 英镑 每场比赛只有 1000 张门票 1 位获胜者是最高得分者 1000 张门票售出 72 小时后 主要卖点 您有千分之一的机会获得获胜技能 在星期一之前设置好将开始通过电话销售售票 使其突出 易于导航和易于支付（找到一种方法），最重要的是显示迄今为止游戏中的人数 有一个部分，他们可以记下销售代理的名称，以便我们可以付款通讯和明显获取客户详细信息等 Splash 网站 - 每周可能达到 60000 人 电话销售 - 很快将达到每周 100,000 人每周 160,000 人都看到或听到在 additi 购买投资物业的消息他们应该看到 1000 英镑有 1000 人有机会赢得改变人生的投资房产 每周 160,000 人 @ 0.25% 转换 – 每周 40,000 英镑 转换的关键是使网站变得流畅和吸引人 易于填写 易于支付玩等，如果你使它光滑简单的销售和吸引力如果它有效，那么在 3 周内你会赠送一个房子公关会做剩下的。 ！今天做明天不存在！使用 Orange 的 BlackBerry® 发送 同时，团队的其他成员正在开发 iPhone 游戏。那里有一些非常有才华的设计师和开发人员——他们制作了一些他们引以为豪的伟大游戏。他们制作了一款名为 Splat（有点像 whack-a-mole）的游戏，这是一种令人上瘾的游戏，并且他们设法让当地的广播电台采访了他们。他们还制作了一款名为 Pigs Might Fly 的游戏——他们全力以赴为这款游戏进行营销。亚历克斯打印了一些大猪标志并将它们贴在氦气球上，然后让它们在曼城中心周围飞来飞去。他们让每个人都给广播电台发短信，说“我刚刚在曼彻斯特看到一只飞猪从我的车旁飘过”，然后他们把其中的一些读出来，问是否有人知道这是关于什么的。然后有人打电话给广播节目并开始播放该应用程序。我刚刚发现公司的 Twitter、Flickr 和 YouTube 帐户仍然有效，而且一切都在那里：争论的焦点是安德鲁希望他们淘汰尽可能多的应用程序，然后等待它们中的任何一个是否受到关注。但是他们想选择一个想法并花几个月的时间来研究它，以完成一份体面的工作。
在我完成将 Skill Buy 转换为新格式后，它不需要任何正在进行的工作，直到它拥有所需的用户，因此我被要求加入团队构建应用程序的其余部分。我们被分配到三人一组：每组两名开发人员和一名设计师。我们必须每周为每个小组制作 10 个应用程序。因此，每个开发人员都必须每天制作一个应用程序，设计师创建我们需要的任何资产。我们刚刚列出了一些你可以毫不费力地做出的糟糕想法。它们大多是选择题测验，或者是一个做了一些傻事的按钮。我使用 PhoneGap 来引导应用程序、创建图标和元数据，并仅在技能购买服务器上托管的 PHP 脚本中编写应用程序逻辑。这些应用程序看起来很糟糕，它们毫无意义，也没有潜力。但我们正在达到我们的目标。 Andrew 还向我们提供了他自己的想法，例如“咨询专家”系列，我们将构建一个您可以向其提交问题的应用程序，然后“专家”会做出回应。他似乎认为自己认识一些专家。大约在这个时候，发生在鲍勃身上的同样的事情也发生在亚历克斯身上——他只是进来大喊“我完了，Cya！”走了出去。我们知道他一定是安德鲁日常工作的接班人。我自己和安德鲁也有类似的经历。有一天，房地产行业的 Web 开发人员生病了，我被要求为他做准备，因为 Andrew 已被承诺在当天结束时将准备好一些新功能。房地产业务的 Steph 向我介绍了情况，我与开发商进行了 Google 聊天。我按要求做了，斯蒂芬对此很满意。我被叫去把它展示给 Andrew，他似乎相信这不是他要求的——所以他嘲笑这项工作，称之为浪费时间，告诉我“回到应用程序”然后继续在我离开时对斯蒂芬大喊大叫。所以我们继续了一会儿。我们制作了蹩脚的应用程序。我们达到了目标。我们告诉我们 19 岁的老板，我们不能再这样下去了，这些应用程序都不会成功。我决定是时候继续前进了。我一直等到月底，确保我收到了报酬，然后礼貌地告诉利亚姆我要离开了。他们从来没有给我合同，所以我没有通知期或任何事情。我刚刚离开并开始寻找新的东西。大约一个月后，我遇到了一位设计师，他说有一天 Andrew 关闭了他们，他们都失业了。很遗憾我的第一份真正的工作只持续了大约 4 个月，但这是一次疯狂的旅程和疯狂的经历。直到现在我还没有真正考虑过那段时间。回想起来，感觉很奇怪，故事看起来很超现实，所以我想写下来。安德鲁很有个性，但与加兹相比，他算不了什么。我认为 Gaz 是 Andrew 最年长也是最好的朋友。当安德鲁赚到钱时，他聘请了加兹作为他的司机/保镖。盖兹看起来像个保镖。他是那些你一见钟情的人之一——但他真的很令人愉快，很乐意与之交谈。一天，我们听到一辆汽车在停车场周围行驶，发出很大的噪音。安德鲁刚买了一辆玛莎拉蒂作为送给 Gaz 的“礼物”——开车送他进去，他们正在工业区转了几圈。自然，这辆车被称为 Gazerati。在网上搜索这篇文章时，我看到了一篇题为房地产开发商被判缓刑的新闻文章，它的开头是：
安德鲁·约翰·卡米勒里 (Andrew John Camilleri) 是一名曾与破产的房地产公司 Fresh Start Living 有关联的商人，他被曼彻斯特刑事法院的陪审团一致判定在个人自愿安排提案中作出虚假陈述。 placenorthwest.co.uk 它还指出，在 2011 年初，安德鲁向债权人作出虚假陈述，试图消除 900 万英镑的债务。因此，他不是百万富翁，而是相反——一个消极的百万富翁。似乎像 App Start Ltd 一样的 Fresh Start Living 已不复存在。

Nearly ten years ago I graduated with a degree in Mathematics & Computing, with a keen interest in pursuing a career involving maths and programming, but with little idea how. First and foremost I had decided to stay in Manchester after uni, rather than risk getting stuck at my parents’ if I moved back home. So I rented a flat with a friend from uni and started looking for a job. I had spent a lot of time at uni learning web development – not so much from the course, but self-taught as the course was quite far behind. I was happily making websites with the LAMP stack, I felt pretty capable at it and I knew there were plenty of such jobs in the Manchester area – so I started applying for “Web developer” and “PHP developer” and similar positions in all sorts of local companies.
 The first interview I had was a general developer job in a small company in Stockport – the job required Microsoft Access experience, and for some reason this was still something I considered myself to have, and was willing to promise to others I had, which baffles me now. I ended up having a really great chat with the company boss at the interview. He asked some great interview questions about data analysis, and we spent about 90 minutes in conversation – he was fascinated by what I’d studied at uni – particularly data visualisation and dynamical systems & chaos. I did get offered the job but he was too late – I’d already had my second interview and they asked me to start immediately.
 My second interview was with a company called  App Start in an office building in an old fashioned industrial estate in a horrible part of Salford (if you think of Media City as  Salford, the rest Salford would be a shock). I was pushing it for time due to underestimating the walk from the train station, and I arrived a bit flustered from the rush and trying to find the place. I was greeted by a man in beach shorts and flip-flops. I was dressed in a full suit, shirt, tie and smart shoes, and I told him “I’m here for an interview with Chris” – his response “Oh, Chris doesn’t work here any more” should have set off alarm bells, but hey, I was young and naive.
   The guy in flip-flops, Alex, seemed to be in charge now. He asked which role I’d applied for – I said “web developer” and he invited me in. There were about 15-20 people working at desktop PCs. There was a big sofa. The floor was bare concrete. In between whiteboards with passwords written on them you could see the walls were graffitied. The “interview” involved him trying to find my CV in Chris’s inbox, and me showing him some websites I’d made. He asked if I could come in the next day, to do a day’s work as a trial – so I did.
 The next day was a Friday – and I seem to recall building a prototype of a social networking site – although I’m not sure why. Anyway – he seemed to think I was good enough so he offered me the job – starting on Monday – which was great for me – I’d landed a full-time job starting straight away, meaning I could pay the rent and start my post-uni life in Manchester. But once I accepted, he asked “are you free tomorrow?” – I hesitated but answered the question – “yes”. “Can you come in?” and because I wasn’t sure what else to say, I said yes. Again, this should have been a sign.
 The owner was a young entrepreneur called Andrew, who I was told had made millions through his property development and management company,  Fresh Start Living. He decided to get into the “app” market (remember, this was 2011 – iPhone apps were huge) and so he’d decided to give his IT guy (Alex) a budget to hire some developers to make a load of apps. Surely one of them would be a huge success and he’d make millions.
  I went back again on the Saturday to find no sign of anyone in the office. I waited around a bit but didn’t know what to do. I didn’t have a contact number for Alex. After a while, he showed up. He’d been in the Fresh Start Living side of the building. We did a day’s work on our own in the office. He gave me a lift home and I was due to start work for real on the Monday.
 I arrived on Monday, and was told about the project I’d be working on. The short version is that I was told we had to have it finished before anyone could go home. We were there until 9pm. That was my first day as a full-time employee.
   So on my first day, Alex told me the project I’d be working on was called  Skill Buy, and proceeded to explain the concept. The idea was similar to an auction site that was popular at the time where you could bid on a product, but you paid for every bid – so if you saw an iPhone with a winning bid of 1p, you could bid 2p, but if you were outbid, you’d lost your 2p – eventually someone would win it at a bargain price at the expense of everyone who’d bid before them and the company would make a fortune. They’re called penny auctions and you can read about them in this paper:    Are online penny auctions a form of gambling? Anyway – the idea I’d been told about was similar, but instead of bidding, you’d play a game (a  Flash or  Unity game made by the game devs I was working with) – and it worked like an arcade game – the winner gets the prize. You’d buy credits, spend your credits playing games, and if you were the top scorer at the end of the game’s countdown timer, you’d win the prize. Actually you’d win the prize at 99% discount because they seemed to think that got around gambling laws.
 Without a web developer on staff, getting this idea off the ground had proved tricky, and Alex had been using his own jack-of-all-trades skills to knock something together. He had some experience managing an e-commerce site (I later found out that he ran his own online sex toy shop…) so he’d put together a Skill Buy prototype using the PHP e-commerce framework  Magento. He would add products (prizes) in the site’s admin area, and hacked away at the templates to show countdown timers and things. Somehow, Alex had promised the site would be ready to show Andrew the next day – and at some point in the afternoon he started to stress out and said to the whole room “no-one’s going home until this is done”. One of the game devs, had made a target shooting practice game in  Unity, and we had to figure out how to embed it in the site and get the game to submit the player’s score to the site’s PHP back-end. We had no idea where to start, but we worked on it all afternoon, well into the evening, and we got it working to whatever standard Alex had required, and finally got to go home.
  Over the next few weeks I worked on the site, I grew fed up of being stuck in this e-commerce framework – having to work with its hyper-normalised MySQL database (the  EAV model), and the fact the product I was building wasn’t really a shop – so I asked Alex if he minded me writing something custom instead. I got my own custom PHP/MySQL site up-and-running pretty quickly, and it didn’t take long before we launched the site. I was happy enough writing crappy PHP, implementing questionable security protections (feeble attempts to block people from sending in fake scores), and learning things like how to integrate Facebook Login, PayPal payments, using AJAX, and working with the game devs to integrate with the scoring system. I actually quite enjoyed working there for a little while! It was liberating, knowing I was using my self-taught web dev skills on my own terms – and getting paid to do so.
   The apps company was being run by Alex and a 19-year-old kid called Liam, whose Uncle was involved in the property business. Somehow Liam had been given an experimental side-project business to help run as his “placement year” at uni.
  One thing that might strike you as odd is the bizarre graphics. The designer had made all these cow-in-a-field graphics for an iPhone game that was planned – but they’d shelved it and told her to re-use them on the website. She  hated that they were being used like this – and it didn’t make sense to anyone else either.
 Alex had a tendency of regularly asking if you were free on Saturday. The first few times I said yes, and just worked an extra day – I think I assumed I would automatically get paid overtime – but I didn’t. Eventually I just learned to say no.
 A little while after I joined, a guy called Bob turned up and took some kind of product manager job, similar to Alex and Liam. Like Liam, he seemed nice enough but somewhat out of place. He was a friend of Alex’s. He used to stare at Google Analytics all day and come over and tell me things about bounce times and referrals. He used to leave after lunch, for whatever reason, so he earned the nickname  Half-a-job Bob. He didn’t last long though. One day, he’d been in a meeting with Andrew, who’d obviously seen through him and had enough. I came to discover that when Andrew decided he didn’t like someone, rather than fire them, he’d have a go at them and make them feel so angry they’d want to leave. Bob marched through the door, slammed it behind him, muttering loudly to himself “he’s not talking to me like that” and declared to the room that he was “taking no more of Andrew’s shit” and stormed out.
  We’d launched the site, and they’d started running Facebook ads promoting it. Alex even ordered a load of printed materials and signs to put up. I remember once, when giving me a lift home, he pulled up and got out of the car to cable tie a Skill Buy banner to a railing at a set of traffic lights.  We had people playing – you got a few free credits after signing up, and some were actually buying credits too. The cheaper gimmicky prizes had short timers on them, and we had winners claim prizes – which Liam shipped out. We had some big prizes on there too, like a Rolex watch, a year’s free accommodation, and a house. The idea was that Andrew could give away use of some of Fresh Start’s rental properties and even a house, if the website made enough revenue. The accommodation and the house were on a 3-month timer, and  surely that would be enough time to build up the site user base.
  After a while, Andrew decided to make a change. Instead of buying credits, you would buy a ticket for a game, and only when enough people had bought a ticket would the game open, to guarantee the revenue covered the cost of the prize. This basically halted all activity on the site. Rather than people playing games and competing for prizes, they were just waiting, and hardly anyone was interested in buying tickets. It meant that the site was no longer spending any money on prizes, so it didn’t have any outgoings, but there wasn’t any sign of it getting the number of users it needed.
 While searching my inbox for anything related to App Start, I found this email from Andrew, forwarded to me by Alex:
 Hi Ben – These are the skill buy changes required by andrew. Begin forwarded message: Make a skill buy section for property prizes only to replace any current property sections Show 3 options talk about yields based on owning them cash 1 terraced house 1 appartment @ bispham 3 student pods montgomery Call all of there values 100 k plus   A ticket to enter costs 100 pounds only 1000 tickets available per game 1 winner is the highest scorer 72 hrs after the 1000 ticket is sold Main selling points you give a 1 in 1000 chance of having the skill to win Have it set up by monday as I will start selling tickets via telesales Make it prominent easy to navigate and easy to pay( find a way)  and most importantly show number of people in the game to date Have a section where they can note the name of the sales agent so we can pay comms  and obviously take clients details etc Splash sites – probably hit 60000 people per week Tele sales – will soon hit 100000 pple per week 160,000 people per week all see or hear the message buy a investment property in addition they should see 100 pounds 1 in 1000 chance to win a life changing investment property 160,000 people per week @ 0.25 percent conversion – 40,000 pounds per week The key to the conversion is making the site slick and appealing easy to fill in easy to pay easy to play etc if you make it slick simple salesy and appealing  If it works then in 3 weeks you would be giving away a house pr will do the rest.  ! Do it today tomorrow doesn’t exist ! Sent using BlackBerry® from Orange
   Meanwhile, the rest of the team was working on iPhone games. There were some really talented designers and developers there – and they produced some great games they were rightly very proud of. They made a game called  Splat (a bit like whack-a-mole) which was one of those addictive games, and they managed to get a local radio station to interview them about it. They also made a game called  Pigs Might Fly – and they went all out with the marketing for this one. Alex got some large pig signs printed and attached them to helium balloons and sent them flying around Manchester City centre. They got everyone to text the radio station saying things like “I’ve just seen a flying pig float past my car in Manchester” and they read a few of them out and asked if anyone knew what it was about. Someone then called in to the radio show and went on air to promote the app. I’ve just found the company  Twitter,  Flickr and  YouTube accounts are still live and it’s all there:
  A point of contention was that Andrew wanted them to knock out as many apps as possible, and wait to see if any of them got traction. But they wanted to choose an idea and spend a few months working on it, to do a decent job.
  Once I’d finished converting Skill Buy to its new format, it didn’t need any ongoing work until it had the users it needed, so I was asked to join the rest of the team building apps. We were assigned to groups of three: two developers and a designer in each. We had to make 10 apps per group every week. So each developer had to make an app a day, with the designer creating any assets we needed. We just listed off a load of crappy ideas for things that you could make without any effort. They were mostly either a multiple-choice quiz, or a button that did something silly. I was using PhoneGap to bootstrap the apps, create the icons and metadata, and just writing the app logic in PHP scripts which were hosted on the Skill Buy server. The apps looked terrible, they were pointless and had no potential. But we were hitting our targets. Andrew also fed us his own ideas, such as the “Ask an expert” series, where we’d build an app you could submit questions to, and an “expert” would respond. He seemed to think he knew some experts.
 Around this time, the same thing that happened to Bob had happened to Alex – he just came in and shouted “I’m done, Cya!” and walked out. We knew he must have been on the receiving end of Andrew’s routine.
 I had a similar experience with Andrew myself. One day, the web developer in the property business was off sick and I was asked to cover for him, because Andrew had been promised that some new feature was going to be ready by the end of that day. I was briefed by Steph from the property business, and I had a Google Chat open with the developer. I did what was asked, and Steph was happy with it. I was called in to present it to Andrew, who seemed to believe that this was not was he’d asked for – so he ridiculed the work, called it a waste of time, told me to “go back to apps” and proceeded to yell at Steph as I was leaving.
 So we continued for a little while. We made our crappy apps. We hit our targets. We told our 19-year-old boss that we can’t go on like this, that none of these apps were going to succeed. I decided it was time to move on. I waited to the end of the month, made sure I’d been paid and I politely told Liam I was leaving. They had never given me a contract, so I didn’t have a notice period or anything. I just left and started looking for something new. I bumped into one of the designers a month or so later and he said that one day Andrew just closed them down and they all lost their jobs.
 It’s a shame my first real job only lasted about 4 months, but it was a wild ride and a crazy experience. I haven’t really thought about that time much until now. Looking back, it feels so strange and the story seems so surreal, so I felt like writing about it.
   Andrew was quite the character, but he was nothing compared to Gaz. I think Gaz was Andrew’s oldest and best friend. When Andrew made his money, he hired Gaz to be his driver / bouncer. Gaz looked like a bouncer. He was one of those people who you were terrified of at sight – but he was genuinely pleasant and nice to talk to. One day, we heard a vehicle driving around the car park making a lot of noise. Andrew had just purchased a  Maserati as a “present” for Gaz – to drive him around in, and they were doing laps of the industrial estate. Naturally, this car became known as the  Gazerati.
 While researching online for this article, I came across a news article entitled   Property developer given suspended prison sentence, which starts:
 Andrew John Camilleri, a businessman formerly associated with wound-up property company Fresh Start Living, has been unanimously convicted by a jury at Manchester Crown Court of making false representations in an Individual Voluntary Arrangement proposal.
 placenorthwest.co.uk
 It also states that in early 2011, Andrew made false representations to creditors in attempt to wipe out debts of £9m. So rather than being a millionaire, he was actually the opposite – a negative millionaire. And it seems Fresh Start Living, like App Start Ltd, is no more.

10 年前，拉里、谢尔盖和塞巴斯蒂安让我有机会进行一项盛大的实验——建造一座登月工厂。最初，我们对 X 到底要做什么只有一个模糊的想法，但我们知道我们想要创建一个可以发明和推出突破性技术的组织，使世界变得更加美好。我们知道 X 可以为 Google 发挥重要作用，超越其核心互联网业务并解决创新者的困境。我同意共同创立 X，因为我一直想创建一个可以反复产生突破性创新的组织，其中充满了极具创造力的人和怪异的想法。当时激励我的是现在激励我：人类选择将其大部分潜力排除在外，未部署和未充分利用。许多人从事的工作并不是为了满足而设计的，还有更多人根本没有机会做出贡献。与此同时，许多强大的组织被迫以牺牲其他一切为代价，专注于自己的盈利能力和短期目标——保持现状不变，或者充其量只是让世界逐渐变得更好。然而，本世纪我们面临的巨大问题需要最广泛的思想、最疯狂的想象力以及大量的时间、资源和注意力。 X 作为一个整体是我们针对这种需求的原型解决方案。我们一直在努力为具有巨大积极影响的激进思想、技术和企业以及最大限度发挥创造力、才能和个人目标感的员工打造工厂。我们希望证明“造福世界”可以带来经济回报，从而激励更多组织像这样运作。这个实验进行了 10 年，我们为迄今为止的工作感到自豪，无论是从 X 开始的许多独立公司和 Google 产品，还是将 X DNA 带入许多不同公司和行业的数百名校友。也就是说，我们还能做更多的事情。在我们成立 10 周年之际，我一直在评估我们在建立一个释放激进创造力的组织方面的表现，同时继续坚持不懈地专注于真正的技术和现实世界的影响。我逐渐意识到，我们的主要文化斗争是对抗恐惧和对传统思维和行为方式的强烈引力。多年来，我们所有人都习惯于不失败，不脆弱，并尽量减少风险。所以我的首要工作是帮助 Xers 重置并摆脱这些无形但有害的限制，以便他们可以释放自己的潜力。这是我希望更多领导者承担的使命，因此以下是我们在帮助团队摆脱平凡并进入意想不到和未知的过程中学到的一些经验教训。 #1 不要以为你可以预测未来。这是投资者、媒体和整个“未来主义”行业流传的最大神话之一；在知道哪些业务和产品从长远来看会取得成功方面，没有人比随机更好。我们的方法：尝试大胆的事情，并在错误时尽快找出答案。可以预测更有可能出现新机会的一般区域；例如，我们认为机器学习有机会在农业、药物发现和新材料开发等领域释放登月规模的机会。但你实际上必须跳进去开始尝试，才能获得“啊哈！”的细节。突破对。有时你会学到一些严厉的教训；这才是重点。有时需要几十次迭代； X 的一个团队目前正在致力于改善人们的聆听方式，他们探索了 35 种不同的想法，然后才找到了我们要大力支持的想法。 #2 放眼长远——它改变了一切。我们特意选择在 5 到 10 年内解决难题。这为我们提供了探索、实验和更深入学习的空间。着眼长远，我们不仅能够考虑我们正在构建的应用程序的影响，还能确保我们考虑到受任何新技术影响的许多不同人群的需求。例如，我们决定解决制造完全自动驾驶汽车的更长、更艰难的道路，而不是推出部分自主的“高速公路助手”功能，因为我们想帮助那些根本不会开车的人，让道路变得安全。可能的。通过长期思考，我们可以优化单个项目和我们的投资组合，以获得尽可能多的积极影响，即使我们无法确切知道哪些赌注会取得巨大成功。
#3 为有创造力和怪异的灵魂开辟空间。威利旺卡不得不建造一个巧克力工厂来容纳 Oompa Loompas，因为他们在野外生存困难。创新者和梦想家通常无法在典型的组织中茁壮成长。他们不断的“假设”和“为什么一定要这样”对于试图锁定执行计划并实现季度目标的组织来说可能会令人恼火。结果，随着时间的推移，他们的创造精神会慢慢屈服于为现状服务，或者他们离开，可能会被贴上麻烦制造者的标签（具有讽刺意味的是，这种情况经常发生在老板聘请“创新顾问”时）。不要误会我的意思 - 执行很重要，尤其是当您进行大规模运营时。但是激进的创新需要不同于产品交付的文化环境。这就是为什么 X 是在 Google 之外成立的。这就是为什么一旦重点从实验和原型设计转移到可靠地运送产品和扩展业务，我们的登月项目就会离开 X。 #4 像孩子一样梦想，像大人一样测试。只要保持足够的乐观去尝试，你就能走得比你想象的更远。你会惊讶于有多少人在一个极其困难的问题中找到动力和快乐，特别是如果它有一个听起来很神奇的解决方案。这就是为什么我们经常说 10X 实际上比 10% 更容易。在这看起来可能之前，X 的团队相信自动驾驶汽车、自动飞行无人机和平流层互联网气球的可能性，现在所有这些都成为现实。我们选择以不同的方式看待世界，并保持孩子般的好奇心和无限的机会。与此同时，我们在运行测试时坚持我们的怀疑态度，并学会冷静地看待结果，所以我们准备改变路线或在正确的时候走开。 #5 寻找神圣的时刻——它们可以让你比明确的目标更进一步。我们让我们的项目去探索新的空间，而没有大量量化的目标，因为我们希望他们能够自由地找到导致最大惊喜的有趣路径。但很难抗拒一个明确的里程碑的诱惑，因为人类不喜欢不确定性，并且发自内心地感受到失败的负面影响，远比我们想象的变革性成功的回报要容易得多。为了解决这个问题，我们告诉团队我们希望他们尝试一系列实验，当他们发现一些让我们说“天哪”的东西时回来。一个机器人导航到一张桌子上，并用它的手臂从垃圾中抓取和分类可回收物。或者四轮越野车在田野中滚动，用激光瞄准和清除杂草。这些不是产品——但它们是我们当前几个新技术能力项目的示范，这些项目预示着他们有能力在未来用机器人技术和农业做更多有趣的事情。 #6 培养热情冷静的能力。虽然我们无法预测未来，但我们正在努力有效地发明它，以最大限度地发挥我们的努力和资源的影响。因此，绝对有必要在智力上诚实并扼杀非常好的东西（即使我们爱它们！），以便我们可以继续寻找更好的机会。这是我们一直在努力做得更好更快的事情，尽管这非常不自然。杀死项目绝非易事。多年来，我们不得不解散数十个团队，放弃数百个绝妙的想法，包括由海水制成的碳中和燃料。对自己的愿景充满热情的企业家通常需要接受指导，让他们定期抬起头来，转变思维方式，冷静地评估自己的处境。有时人们对我们说：“你必须继续这样做，因为没有其他人会这样做。”但这没有抓住重点。是的，我们希望投资具有巨大前景的远期技术，而这些技术仍然具有如此高的风险，其他人都不会这样做。但是，在某些时候，一旦我们对该技术的风险有所降低感到满意，我们就需要测试其商业可行性。如果市场和我们一样兴奋，其他公司也会投入资金，我们会继续前进。但如果他们不这样做，那么也许我们一直在自欺欺人，我们应该走开，将我们的时间、资源和人才重新分配到更有前途的解决方案上。 #7 创建无畏的混沌飞行员团队。唯一的发明家有一个尤里卡时刻在很大程度上是一个神话；创新来自伟大的团队。这并不意味着委员会或共识的创新。这是关于承诺一起工作并互相支持，因为我们要去哪里，我们知道很多时候它会是黑暗和颠簸的。我们特意将来自不同背景、文化和社区的团队聚集在一起，这样我们就可以产生更多创造性的想法并提出尖锐的问题。前火箭科学家与音乐会钢琴家和木偶师一起工作，海洋生物学家与物理学家和机器学习专家打交道。最重要的是，我们努力创造一个环境，让每个人都能轻松地分享他们的观点，并且喜欢奔向真正困难的问题，正是因为它们很困难。 X 本身就是一个登月计划，但与 X 的大多数事情不同，我们的突破性想法不是一项技术。是我们的人。它是关于设计一种文化并设计一个组织，以克服导致人类退回到舒适和传统的强大力量。这些力量扼杀了任何以增量方式创新和解决问题的努力。因此，我致力于寻找一系列实践，例如上述那些，可以帮助许多个人和组织重新调整自己，因此大胆、以目标为导向、以团队为导向的协作可以成为情绪阻力最小的途径——因此是通往解决 21 世纪面临的诸多挑战。

10 years ago Larry, Sergey, and  Sebastian offered me the chance to run a grand experiment — to build a moonshot factory. Initially we only had a fuzzy idea about exactly what X was going to do, but we knew we wanted to create an organization that could invent and launch breakthrough technologies that would make the world a radically better place. And we knew X could play an important role for Google, in reaching beyond its core Internet business and beating the  innovator’s dilemma. I agreed to co-found X because I’ve always wanted to create an organization that could repeatedly generate breakthrough innovations filled with hyper-creative people and weird, out-there thinking.
 What motivated me then is what motivates me now: humanity is choosing to keep much of its potential off the table, undeployed, and underutilized. Many people go to work at jobs that aren’t designed to be fulfilling, and many more don’t get the chance to contribute at all. Meanwhile, many powerful organizations are forced to focus on their own profitability and short term goals at the expense of everything else — leaving the status quo intact, or at best only making the world incrementally better. Yet the massive problems facing us this century need the widest array of minds, the wildest imaginations, and enormous commitments of time, resources, and attention.
  X as a whole is our prototype solution to this need. We’ve been trying to make a factory for radical ideas, technologies, and businesses that will have a huge positive impact, and for employees who maximize their creativity, talent, and personal sense of purpose. And we hope to prove that “good for the world” can be financially rewarding, so that more organizations are inspired to operate like this. 10 years into this experiment, we’re proud of our work so far, whether it’s the many  standalone companies and Google products that started at X or the hundreds of alumni who carry X DNA into many different companies and industries. That said, there’s still more we can do.
 As we hit our 10th anniversary, I’ve been taking stock of how we’re doing at building an organization that unleashes radical creativity while remaining relentlessly focused on real technologies and real-world impact. What I’ve come to realize is that our main cultural battle is against fear and the strong gravitational pull toward conventional ways of thinking and behaving. All of us have been conditioned for years not to fail, not to be vulnerable, and to minimize risk. So my number one job is helping Xers reset and free themselves from these invisible but pernicious constraints so they can free up their potential. And it’s a mission I want more leaders to take on, so below are some of the lessons we’ve learned about helping teams break away from the ordinary and into the unexpected and unknown.
  #1 Stop thinking you can predict the future. This is one of the biggest myths perpetuated by investors, media, and the entire “futurist” industry; no one is much better than random at knowing what businesses and products will succeed in the long run. Our approach: Try audacious things and figure out as quickly as you can when you’re wrong.
 It’s possible to predict general territories where new opportunities are more likely to lie; for example, we think machine learning has the opportunity to unlock moonshot-sized opportunities in areas like agriculture, drug discovery, and the development of new materials. But you actually have to jump in and start trying things in order to get the details of that “Ah-ha!” breakthrough right. Sometimes you learn some  harsh lessons; that’s the point. Sometimes it takes dozens of iterations; one team at X right now is working on improving how people hear, and they explored 35 different ideas before they found the one we’re going to pour fuel on.
 #2 Take a long term view — it changes everything. We’ve deliberately chosen to work on hard problems whose answers are 5–10 years over the horizon. This gives us space to explore and experiment and learn more deeply. Taking the long view also enables us to think through the implications not just the applications of what we’re building, and ensure we’re taking into account the needs of many different people affected by any new technology. For example, we decided to tackle the longer, harder path of creating fully self-driving cars instead of launching a partially autonomous “freeway assistant” feature, because we wanted to  help people who couldn’t drive at all and make roads as safe as possible. By thinking long term, we can optimize individual projects and our portfolio for as much positive impact as possible, even if we can’t know exactly which bets will work out in a big way.
  #3 Carve out space for creative and weird souls. Willy Wonka had to build a chocolate factory to house the Oompa Loompas, because they struggled to survive in the wild. And innovators and dreamers often can’t thrive in typical organizations. Their constant “what ifs” and “why does it have to be this ways” can be irritating for organizations trying to lock in an execution plan and meet quarterly targets. As a result, their creative spirit is slowly bent over time to serve the status quo, or they leave, maybe branded as troublemakers (ironically, this often happens when the bosses hire “innovation consultants”). Don’t get me wrong — execution matters, especially when you’re operating at scale. But radical innovation needs a different cultural environment than product delivery does. That’s why X was set up away from Google. It’s why our moonshot projects leave X once the focus shifts from experimentation and prototyping to shipping products reliably and scaling a business.
  #4 Dream like a child, test like a grownup. You can get way further than you think just by being optimistic enough to try. You’d be surprised how many people find motivation and joy in a ridiculously hard problem, especially if it has a magical-sounding solution. This is why we’ve  often said that 10X can actually be easier than 10%. Before it seemed possible, teams at X believed in the possibility of self-driving cars, self-flying delivery drones, and stratospheric Internet-beaming balloons, and now all of these things are becoming real. We choose to see the world differently and keep our child-like sense of wonder and boundless opportunity. At the same time, we hold on to our skepticism as we run tests and learn to look dispassionately at the results, so we’re ready to change course or walk away when that is the right thing to do.
 #5 Look for holy s**t moments — they can get you further than clear objectives. We send our projects off to explore new spaces without heavily quantified goals because we want them feeling free to find the intriguing paths that lead to the biggest surprises. But it’s hard to resist the allure of a clear milestone because humans dislike uncertainty and viscerally feel the downsides of failure far more easily than we can imagine the rewards of transformative success. To counteract this, we tell teams we want them to try a bunch of experiments and come back when they’ve found something that makes us say “holy s**t.” A robot navigates up to a table and uses its arm to  grasp and sort recyclables from trash. Or a  four-wheeled buggy rolls through a field, targeting and zapping weeds with a laser. These aren’t products — but they are demonstrations from a couple of our current projects of new technical capabilities that are harbingers of their ability to do even more interesting things with robotics and in agriculture in the future.
  #6 Cultivate the ability to be passionately dispassionate. While we can’t predict the future, we’re trying to invent it efficiently, to maximize the impact of our effort and resources. So it’s absolutely necessary to be intellectually honest and kill things that are pretty good (even if we love them!) so we can move on to  even  better opportunities. It’s something we keep trying to get better and faster at, though it’s deeply unnatural. It’s never easy to kill projects. Over the years we’ve had to disband dozens of teams and walk away from hundreds of gorgeous ideas, including  a carbon-neutral fuel made from seawater.
 Entrepreneurs who are charging passionately toward their vision often need to be coached to pop their heads up regularly and switch their mindset to dispassionately assess their situation. Sometimes people say to us, “You have to keep going at this because no one else will.” But that misses the point. Yes, we want to invest in far-out technologies with huge promise when they’re still so risky no one else will. At some point, though, once we’re satisfied that the technology has been somewhat de-risked, we need to test its commercial viability. If the market is as excited about it as we are, other companies will put money into it too, and we’ll keep going. But if they won’t, then maybe we’ve been kidding ourselves, and we should walk away and redirect our time, resources, and talent to more promising solutions.
  #7 Create fearless teams of   chaos pilots . The lone inventor having a eureka moment is largely a myth; innovation comes from great teams. This doesn’t mean innovation by committee or consensus. It’s about committing to working together and having each other’s back, because where we’re going, we know it’s going to be dark and bumpy a lot of the time. We deliberately assemble teams from a wide range of backgrounds, cultures, and communities, so we can generate more creative ideas and ask hard questions. Former  rocket scientists work alongside concert pianists and puppeteers, and marine biologists mingle with physicists and machine learning experts. Above all, we work hard to create an environment where everyone feels comfortable sharing their views and loves running toward really hard problems precisely because they’re difficult.
  X is a moonshot in and of itself, but unlike most things at X, our breakthrough idea isn’t a technology. It’s our people. It’s about engineering a culture and designing an organization that can overcome the powerful forces that cause humans to retreat to the comfortable and conventional. These forces stifle any efforts to innovate and problem-solve in more than an incremental way. So I’m committed to finding a set of practices, like the ones above, that help many individuals and organizations reset ourselves so audacious, purpose-driven, team-oriented collaboration can become the path of least emotional resistance — and therefore the path to solving the many challenges facing the 21st century.
 Editor’s note: we’d love to hear your tips, thoughts, and questions in the comments field, and we’ll try to address some of them in a future blog. Want more? Here’s a post from 2016 about   our factory processes , a   TED talk about the unexpected benefits of failure  and thoughts on   how to make teams fearless . In 2018, we created The Gimbal, a document we give to all new Xers that explains our ways of thinking and working, and today we’re making it available to anyone   here .

The owner reports his father-in-law unwittingly bought the upgrade which automatically charged his credit card.
  The last decade saw a proliferation of heart-warming stories where over-eager children bought expensive vehicles or toys using their parent's accounts on phones, tablets or using smart assistants like Alexa. Some of us have the opposite problem, dad-clicking our way into things we shouldn't. Dominic Preuss had this very issue recently, as his father-in-law charged over $14,000 to his credit card by accidentally purchasing the Full Self-Driving upgrade on his Tesla Model 3,  reports  CarScoops.
 The precise charges came out to $14,186.25, for Autopilot and Full Self-Driving plus tax. It's a hefty sum no matter how you cut it. Writing on Twitter, Preuss notes "If you double click the shift panel twice and accidentally engage the auto-pilot in Model 3, Tesla will automatically charge you $14100 if you didn't previously purchase auto-pilot."
   Autopilot and  Full-Self Driving are two of Tesla's headline features it uses to differentiate itself in the marketplace. The incident happened when Preuss's father in law was driving the car, and thus the charges were made without so much as a request for credit card info or any password authorization. The Tesla simply billed the credit card already on file.
   It suggests that anyone, even a child sitting in the car, could easily land a Tesla owner with a huge bill with just a few clicks. An email notification of the purchase alerted Preuss, who was able to cancel the charges. Heading into the "Manage Upgrades" settings let Preuss secure a refund to his credit card.
   The Tesla owner noted that the purchase may have been made through a different method than the one he quoted, but was made without any authorization regardless. Given that even most smartphones require a thumbprint or PIN entry to spend as little as 99 cents, it's a little horrifying that you can get billed fourteen big ones from a couple of mis-swipes by anyone who sits in the car.
 We'd expect Tesla to rectify the issue in a future update, though we can't verify this is on the cards as the company famously doesn't run a press department. In any case, if something similar happens to you, in a Tesla or any other car with subscription-activated features, be sure to drop us a line.
